message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: An Improved Artificial Potential Field Method for Path Planning and Formation Control of the Multi-UAV Systems
Paper Abstract: Path planning and formation control are both challenging and critical issues in robotics, which involve computing an optimal path from the initial position to target while keeping the desired formation. This brief studies the path planning and formation control problem for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) in 3-D constrained space. Considering the local minimum of artificial potential function (APF), an effective improved artificial potential function (IAPF) based path planning approach is proposed for the multi-UAV systems. By introducing a rotating potential field, the UAVs can escape from the common local minimum and oscillations efficiently. Afterwards, by using the leader-follower model, a formation controller based on potential function method is developed to ensure that the follower UAVs keep the desired angles and distances with the leader, and a Lyapunov function is designed to analyze the closed-system stability. Finally, simulation studies under different environmental constraints confirm the efficiency of the proposed approaches in addressing the path planning and formation control issues in 3-D space.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Leadership and Followership Concepts

Followership refers to the actions of someone in a subordinate role, and may be considered as particular services that help the leader, a role within a hierarchical organization, or behaviors engaged in while interacting with leaders to meet organizational objectives.

## Technology Applications

The search results also revealed a related technological concept: In engineering, master–slave (often now called "leader-follower") is a relationship between two systems in which one controls the other, where one master can control just one slave system, but in other cases there are multiple slave systems controlled by the same master.

Examples of these control systems include:
- In hydraulic systems, a master cylinder is a control device that converts force into hydraulic pressure that drives movement in a slave cylinder, with a common application being a vehicle brake system.
- Railway locomotives operating in the same train may be configured for master–slave operation with all but one of the locomotives controlled from the first.

The results primarily focus on organizational leadership theories and technological control systems rather than a specific "leader-follower control systems" field. If you're looking for information about a more specific topic in this area, please let me know!

Links: [{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Path-planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Path-planning&redirect=no"},{"title":"Planning Alternative Tomorrows with Hope - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Alternative_Tomorrows_with_Hope"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*#:~:text=It makes assumptions about the,robot then follows the path."},{"title":"Graphical path method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_path_method"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Flight planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_planning"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of path planning:

## Definition

Path planning (also known as motion planning or the navigation problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves an object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Applications and Uses

Any-angle path planning are useful for robot navigation and real-time strategy games where more optimal paths are desirable.(no content)As a subset of motion planning, it is an important part of robotics as it allows robots to find the optimal path to a target, and this ability to find an optimal path also plays an important role in other fields such as video games and gene sequencing.

## Key Approaches

Several major approaches to path planning include:

- **Any-angle path planning**: Pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

- **Sampling-based algorithms**: These represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations, sampling N configurations and retaining those in free space to use as milestones, then constructing a roadmap that connects two milestones if the line segment between them is completely in free space.

- **Real-time path planning**: Motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, ranging from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously take in information from the surroundings and create a plan to avoid obstacles.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here are the search results for **Lyapunov stability**:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Definition and Key Concepts

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.(no content)Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Significance and Applications

Interest in Lyapunov theory skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Significance and Applications

Interest in Lyapunov theory skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

I've completed a web search for "unmanned aerial vehicle". Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.

## Modern Development and Applications

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications.

Web search results for query: "control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control theory:

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## Key Concepts

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics. Additionally, control theory is routinely applied to problems in the natural and behavioral sciences, and as the general theory of feedback systems, is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Web search results for query: "artificial potential field"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Oussama Khatib - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oussama_Khatib"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"Machine-learned interatomic potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine-learned_interatomic_potential"},{"title":"Interatomic potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interatomic_potential"},{"title":"Force field (chemistry) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_field_(chemistry)"},{"title":"Local field potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_field_potential"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Potential energy surface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_energy_surface"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about artificial potential fields:

## Overview

Artificial potential fields treat the robot's configuration as a point in a potential field that combines attraction to the goal, and repulsion from obstacles.

## Origin and Development

The artificial potential field method was first introduced in 1978, motivated by the pressing need to enable reactive robot operation in unstructured environments, and it has since been adopted and extended by researchers in robotics, graphics, vision, and animation.

## How It Works

Artificial potential fields can be treated as continuum equations similar to electrostatic potential fields (treating the robot like a point charge), or motion through the field can be discretized using a set of linguistic rules.(no content)The resulting trajectory is output as the path, and this approach has advantages in that the trajectory is produced with little computation.

## Limitations

However, artificial potential fields can become trapped in local minima of the potential field and fail to find a path, or can find a non-optimal path.(no content)A navigation function or probabilistic navigation function are sorts of artificial potential functions which have the quality of not having minimum points except the target point.

## Applications

Local path planning using artificial potential fields refers to methods that take in information from the surroundings in order to generate a simulated field where a path can be found, allowing a path to be found in real-time as well as adapt to dynamic obstacles.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Oussama Khatib - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oussama_Khatib"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"Machine-learned interatomic potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine-learned_interatomic_potential"},{"title":"Interatomic potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interatomic_potential"},{"title":"Force field (chemistry) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_field_(chemistry)"},{"title":"Local field potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_field_potential"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Potential energy surface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_energy_surface"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about artificial potential fields:

## Overview

Artificial potential fields treat the robot's configuration as a point in a potential field that combines attraction to the goal, and repulsion from obstacles.

## Origin and Development

The artificial potential field method was first introduced in 1978, motivated by the pressing need to enable reactive robot operation in unstructured environments, and it has since been adopted and extended by researchers in robotics, graphics, vision, and animation.

## How It Works

Artificial potential fields can be treated as continuum equations similar to electrostatic potential fields (treating the robot like a point charge), or motion through the field can be discretized using a set of linguistic rules.(no content)The resulting trajectory is output as the path, and this approach has advantages in that the trajectory is produced with little computation.

## Limitations

However, artificial potential fields can become trapped in local minima of the potential field and fail to find a path, or can find a non-optimal path.(no content)A navigation function or probabilistic navigation function are sorts of artificial potential functions which have the quality of not having minimum points except the target point.

## Applications

Local path planning using artificial potential fields refers to methods that take in information from the surroundings in order to generate a simulated field where a path can be found, allowing a path to be found in real-time as well as adapt to dynamic obstacles.

I've found comprehensive information about robot motion planning. Here's what the search results show:

## Definition and Overview

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.

## Core Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Major Approaches

There are several key algorithmic approaches to robot motion planning:

1. **Sampling-based algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems with dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

2. **Grid-based approaches**: Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. At each grid point, the robot is allowed to move to adjacent grid points as long as the line between them is completely contained within free space. Search algorithms like A* are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

3. **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM)**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes new methods)

**7 Triples Extracted:**

1. **Motion planning** (task) - Uses - Core task of computing optimal paths from initial to target positions in constrained space
2. **Artificial potential field** (method) - Uses - Traditional approach used as foundation for the improved method to address local minima
3. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (artifact) - Uses - Multi-UAV systems are the primary subject of the methods
4. **Control theory** (concept) - Uses - Theoretical foundation for designing controllers and analyzing system stability
5. **Lyapunov stability** (concept) - Uses - Used to analyze and ensure closed-loop system stability of the formation controller
6. **Master–slave (technology)** (concept) - Uses - Leader-follower model is a master-slave control relationship for UAV coordination
7. **Improved artificial potential field method** (method) - Proposes - Novel IAPF method with rotating potential fields to escape local minima

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All requirements met:
- ✅ Paper has contribution type with at least 1 "proposes" relation
- ✅ All papers have at least 1 "uses" relation (building on existing work)
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- ✅ All entity types properly classified

Sources:
- [Motion planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning)
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
- [Master–slave (technology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master%E2%80%93slave_(technology))
